titleStmt.title: question-answer session on issues of steelmaking
titleStmt.funder: VOICE is funded by FWF, the Austrian Science Fund (Project No. L448)

publicationStmt.publisher: Barbara Seidlhofer, Stefan Majewski, Ruth Osimk-Teasdale, Marie-Luise Pitzl, Michael Radeka
publicationStmt.distributor: VOICE Project, University of Vienna, Austria

availability.p: The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (VOICE) was created by Barbara Seidlhofer (project director) and Angelika Breiteneder, Theresa Klimpfinger, Stefan Majewski, Marie-Luise Pitzl (project researchers). Minor revisions were gathered by Ruth Osimk-Teasdale and Michael Radeka and corrections were made by Ruth Osimk-Teasdale. VOICE 2.0 XML is available for download at the VOICE Project's websitehttp://www.univie.ac.at/voice/under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-NC-SA 3.0) License (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/). The original audio files are held at the Department of English, University of Vienna. 23 selected audio files are available as audio streams in the VOICE Online interface at the VOICE Project's websitehttp://www.univie.ac.at/voice.
The recommended citation for VOICE 2.0 XML is:

p.bibl: VOICE.2013.The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English(version 2.0 XML). Director: Barbara Seidlhofer; Researchers: Angelika Breiteneder, Theresa Klimpfinger, Stefan Majewski, Ruth Osimk-Teasdale, Marie-Luise Pitzl, Michael Radeka.

availability.p: The short citation for VOICE 2.0 XML is:

p.bibl: VOICE.2013.The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English(version 2.0 XML).

availability.p: For further information about availability and copyright permissions, please see the README file included in the download package. For further enquiries please contact the VOICE Project atvoice@univie.ac.at.

notesStmt.note: This question-answer session takes place after several presentations on steelmaking at a conference on this topic. S2 has just finished his presentation on a melt shop. S1, S2 and S4 are on the podium, S3 and S5 in the audience, asking questions.

equipment.p: Portable minidisc recorder with electret condenser stereo microphone

namespace.name: http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark a stretch of speech commonly preceded and followed by a pause or by a change of speaker. Auis, however, not required to be bounded by a pause or a change of speaker, nor does it represent a turn in a conversation analytic sense. At a minimum, auis some phonetic production or noise made by a given speaker or a group of speakers.
Used to mark contextual information relevant to the understanding of the interaction or the interaction as such. Thevoice:descattribute provides a short prose description of the contextual event.

Used to mark text supplied by the transcriber because the original is unintelligible or needed to be anonymized. Thereasonattribute is used to mark:
unintelligible
unintelligible speech
anonymization
anonymized speech

Used to mark lengthening of sounds and intonation (fall, rise). The followingtypeattributes are used to mark:
lengthening
lengthened sounds
intonation
a significant change in intonation, marked with the followingfunctionattribute for:
fall
falling intonation
rise
rising intonation
Intonation may or may not coincide with syntactic boundaries.
Used to mark a pause either between or within utterances. Used withoutdurattribute to indicate a brief pause up to half a second.

Used with differenttypeattributes to mark:
type overlap
overlaps
type onomatopoeia
onomatopoeic sounds
type ipa
transcriptions in the international phonetic alphabet

Used to mark the point at which some paralinguistic feature changes. The following attribute values are used to mark:
voice
voice quality
imitating
laugh
neutral
phone
reading
reading_aloud
sigh
singing
whisp
yawning
tempo
speed of utterance
a
accelerando
l
lento
neutral
neutral
loud
loudness
f
neutral
p
Used to mark speech which is stressed or emphasized in a way that goes beyond regular nuclear stress.

Used to mark other-continuation, i.e. whenever a speaker continues another speaker'suwithout a pause. Other-continuation is to be interpreted temporally and does not relate to form or content of the speakers' utterances.
Used to mark speech which cannot be transcribed with certainty, because it is difficult to hear or understand for the transcriber.
Used with thetypeattribute set tospeltto mark words or word fragments which are spelt out, i.e. words whose constituents are pronounced as individual letters.

Used to mark laughter and other speaker noises and non-verbal feedback.
speaker_noise
coughing
nods
shakes head
smacks lips
sniffs
swallows
whistles
wordlike
laughing

namespace.name: http://www.univie.ac.at/voice/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark a pronunciation variation or coinage as described inthe VOICE mark-up conventions [2.1].the VOICE mark-up conventions [2.1]. An existing word corresponding to the PVC may be provided within acommentcomment attribute within thevoice:pvcvoice:pvc element. Additional phonetic transcription may be provided within avoice:ipavoice:ipa attribute within thevoice:pvcvoice:pvc element.
Used to mark the beginning of a new audio track used in transcription (usually three minutes in length) and thus refers to the audio recording of the transcribed speech event.
